publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

sourceDesc.physDesc: [Anon] Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned, and undated. 8p. Paginated 3-10. On verso of p. 8-9 her: People one would have liked to have met. Holograph fragment. 2p.

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

prefixDef.p: In the context of this project, private URIs with the prefix "psn" point to Person elements in the project's `personography.xml` file

l.del: Anon died round 18787. It was the printed book
with the authors name attached that killed him. After that>
the audience was separate from the singer. After that
the song was attached to the singer. Anon gives place to

Geoffrey or
Jogn John or Peter; he lives in a house

p.l:
The heart of this vast
prolieferation proliferation of printed pages
remains the song. The song has the same power over the reader

in the 20th
cen ury century as over the hearer in the 11th. To enjoy
singing, to enjoy hearing the sing, must be the most
deep rooted, the toughest of human instincts comparable
for persistency with the instinct of self preservation
It is indeed the instinct of self preservation.
Only when we put two and two together--two pencil strokes,

two written words, two bricks do we overcome
doissolution dissolution
and set up some stake against oblivion. The passion with

which we seek out these
creation creations and attempt endlessly,
perpetually, to make them is of a piece with the instinct

that sets us preserving
out our bodies, with clothes, food,
roofs, from destruction.
ButWith the printing press broughtcame into existence
forces that cover over the original song--books themselves,
and the readers of books. If science were so advanced that
we could at this moment X ray the singers mindas she moved we should

find a nimbus surrounding the song; a
steeam stream steam of
influences. Some we can name--education; class;
the pressure of society. But they are so many, and so
interwoven and so obscure that it is simpler to invent
for them nonsense names--- say Nin Crot and Pully. Nin
Crot and Pully are always at their work, tugging, obscuring,
distorting. Some are visible only to the writer. Others

only to the reader. More and more
omplex complex do they become as

time passes. The song beneath is only to be
disocovered discovered
in a flash of recognition; Some say they feel it when their
beards bristle; others that a thrill runs down the nerves
of the thigh. But the song is there still. For example:
That babbling, child like, story telling singer, that

gossip at the farm yard door, that
inno ent innocent eyed, naked,

lustful, nowalternately obscene
n and devout singer, who was now and ag
a great artist died in 14787, And with him died
the part of his song that the audience sang--the voice that

filled in pauses, and added sometimes a
nonsenical nonsensical chorus
To follow his fortunes further we must turn to one of those
commentators who tell us us so much about the invisible
influences. about Nin Crot and Pulley.
But for him of course we have to wait until winter
was past; until time has drawn its blue veil
over the horizon; until there is a past. ThenWhen Anon

is
lomg long dead,
adnthe and the Pil Canterbury Pilgrims have gone
their way, somebody looks back. He is a representative man,
that is he h is often repeated, and often , with little variation.
He--Harrison was his name-- is the first of that long line
of leisured and learned men who have time to think about the

past in
hthe the quiet of the parsonage. Like Cole, like Skinner
Harrison the parson of Radwinter, hehad a library; and dug up
coins. He already sees the present against the background

of the past. The past has
necome become so settled, so ordered,

that
yhe the present looks ungainly and degenerate against it.
There is too much comfort; too much silver; too many pillows.

The young Shakespeares, Marlowes are not the men their
father fathers
were. The smoke is drawn off from their sitting rooms

by
chimensy chimneys , so that instead of being salted and
hardned hardened by thesmoke eddying from the fire in the
brazier, they are tender and subject to rheumatism. They

dress most fantastically
comparded compared with their ancestors.
